Title: Merit Aid, College Quality, and College Completion: Massachusetts' Adams Scholarship as an In-Kind Subsidy
Data Comments: "Most of the data for this project is proprietary. It can be obtained from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) by applying to their research office for permission to use the data. Data release is at DESE‚Äôs discretion, and applicants will need to protect student data. The necessary files for replication are the Student Information Management System (SIMS) files from school year 2001-2002 to 2010-2011, the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System (MCAS) test files from school year 2001-2002 to 2010-2011, the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC) records for high school graduates from the classes of 2004-2008. Applicants should also request the list of Adams Scholarship winners to verify the decision rule."
Data Contact: Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education

Title: Keeping It Simple: Financial Literacy and Rules of Thumb
Main Issue: Output data not found. Had to put output into .out files, which are hard to read
Data Comments: "We constructed the original sample frame based on administrative data collected by ADOPEM in the ordinary course of operations. Beginning in November 2006, we conducted a baseline survey of each study participant using a professional survey firm unafiliated with ADOPEM. We collected information on household and business characteristics, business practices and performance, business skills, training history, and interest in future training. The endline survey was conducted during the summer of 2008, at least 12 months after training was completed. We augmented the surveys with administrative data from ADOPEM."ÔªøÔªøÔªøÔªø

Title: How Do Teachers Improve? The Relative Importance of Specific and General Human Capital
Data Comments: "I use longitudinal administrative data that link students to their teachers in the state of North Carolina between 1995-2012.2 These data include detailed informationn on student, classroom, teacher, and school characteristics as well as a standadized measure of math and reading achievement for students in grades three through eight. For each student, the data include race, gender, limited English status, free or reduced lunch status, and test scores for for each grade. Available teacher characteris include gender, race, highest degree earned, years of teaching experience, und graduate institution, and licensure test scores.3 Years of teaching experience is ba on the number of years credited to a teacher for the purposes of salary calculat and thus should reflect all experience in any district."
Data Contact: North Carolina Education Research Data Center (NCERDC) at Duke University

Title: The Great Equalizer: Health Care Access and Infant Mortality in Thailand
Data Comments: "This zip file contains the two programs used to estimate the utilization impacts of the 30 Baht program (analyze_util_vFINAL.do) and the infant mortality impacts of the program (analyze_infant_vFINAL.do). These programs rely on datasets obtained from the National Statistics Office in Thailand. In particular, the utilization analysis requires the Health and Welfare Study (‚ÄúHWS‚Äù) for years 2001, 2003-2005. The infant mortality analysis requires province-level infant mortality statistics. Both datasets were obtained under an understanding that we would not disseminate their data. However, we are happy to assist researchers interested in replication or further analysis"

Title: Human Capital and Productivity in a Team Environment: Evidence from the Healthcare Sector
Data Comments: ‚ÄúWe are requesting an exemption from the AEJ‚Äôs Data Availability Policy because the paper uses data from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs has a data security policy that requires data use agreements before any VA data, including de- identified data, can be moved outside of the VA firewall. This even applies to individuals with dual VA/university appointments who want to move the data to a university computer. This policy is backed up by Federal law, and violations, in extreme cases, can result in fines. While the data cannot be transferred, they are potentially available to non-VA researchers if they are willing to go through the VA data transfer process. Ciaran Phibbs, who is a VA researcher, will assist other researchers in obtaining a data use agreement which, if granted by the VA, would give them access to the actual dataset (constructed variables, not raw data) that we used to estimate the regressions reported in the manuscript. It would be much harder, if not impossible, for a non-VA researcher to obtain access to the raw patient-level data or the VA payroll data that we use in this study; this would require the researcher to collaborate with a VA researcher who could gain access to the data.‚Äù

Title: Cross-Border Media and Nationalism: Evidence from Serbian Radio in Croatia
Main Issue: Output not labeled based on the tables in the article. Tables 6-8 in the article cannot be linked to output from dataset. Significance results stay the same.
Data Comments:
"We construct two measures of the reception of Serbian radio in a village. The  rst measure, which is available for the baseline sample of 139 villages, is based on hand-collected data obtained while travelling throughout the region in June 2009 and June 2010. In the center of each village (near the church or the war monument), we used a portable radio receiver to test whether the RTS Serbian stations were available. We count a radio station as available if its quality was good enough to listen to it based on the subjective assessment of two people. The measure of availability is an indicator for whether at least one RTS radio station is available.
The second measure of reception of Serbian radio is the signal strength con- structed using the location and power of RTS transmitters.10 This measure is available for the extended sample of all 417 villages located within 75 kilometers from the Croatian-Serbian border."

Title: Selection and Economic Gains in the Great Migration of African Americans: New Evidence from Linked Census Data
Data Comments: The authors a new panel dataset of more than 5,000 men matched from the 1910 to 1930 census manuscripts. "First, as mentioned above, we have created a new dataset that matches south- ern-resident African American males from the public-use microdata sample of the 1910 Census of Population (Ruggles et al. 2010) to the same men in the hand- written manuscripts of the 1930 census. We have transcribed key variables on labor market outcomes from the 1930 manuscripts. The resulting linked dataset includes an extensive set of personal, family, and local characteristics for more than 5,000 black males before and after the start of the Great Migration."

Title: Meet the Press: How Voters and Politicians Respond to Newspaper Entry and Exit
Data Comments: This paper uses an original dataset covering the presence of local news in medium-large Italian cities in the period 1993- 2010. The data comes from a variety of sources, including: es. The Italian Authority for Communication (AGCOM)'s annual reports, detailed information from Lenzi (2001), Iannace (1989) and Grandinetti (2008), the information contained in the "Grande Libro della Stampa Italiana," and website archive.org

Title: Demand Spillovers, Combative Advertising, and Celebrity Endorsements
Data Comments: The authors use sales and return data at the point of sale from Nielsen‚Äôs BookScan panel, a proprietary point-of-sale dataset representing approximately 75 percent of total US book sales. "These data come from chain booksellers such as Borders, Barnes and Noble, and Books-a-Million, as well as a large number of independent booksellers. BookScan also receives data from online retailers such as Amazon.com, and Powells.com. It does not collect data for sales that occur at Wal-Mart, many grocery stores, or for the sales of electronic books." "This analysis uses title-level data from January 2001 to June 2011 and aggregate sales data from January 2004 to June 2011."

Title: Small Steps for Workers, a Giant Leap for Productivity
Data Comments:
"Our study and data focus on the production of billets in the melt shop of a vertically integrated steelmaker." They limit the study to a single plant. The shop produces a homogeneous goods such that they can measure outputs in physical units. Capital is also well-defined that the shop used the same furnace. There is no labor turnover, and with these conditions, the authors are granted access to very detailed cost and production data. "We have daily data from May 2001 to August 2009 (though daily data is for June 2001) on production, output, every input utilized, and the time spent duction and on delays. In what follows, we will study data only until September 2008, the pick of the financial crisis. The reason to stop at this point is that the crisis had an impact on the profitability of production. Following September 2008, the
 melt shop chose, for the first time at least since January 1997, to operate at less than full capacity. For January 1997 to April 2001, we only have monthly data on production"

Title: Improving Educational Quality through Enhancing Community Participation: Results from a Randomized Field Experiment in Indonesia
Main Issue: Error in the code. Only some tables can be produced
Data Comments: Data files:1. intermediate_outcomes.dta is a dataset at the school level.2. treat_AEJ.dta is a dataset at the school level.3. test_score.dta is a balanced panel dataset at the student level.4. attrition.dta is a dataset at the student level. "We matched students on the basis of student names written on the test sheets and school ID. We were able to match 10,941 students, which is equal to 87 percent of the tests administered at baseline in grade four, and 88 percent of the tests admin- istered at endline in grade six, in the 517 schools that participated in both rounds." "We also designed surveys centered around hypothesized mechanisms that could improve learning outcomes. Broadly, these intermediate outcomes relate to stake- holder awareness of school committees, school-based management, parent, com- munity and teacher inputs to education. We interviewed parents, teachers, students, school committee members, and principals. Administrative data and interviewer observations on infrastructure and teacher activities at the start of visit were also recorded. Because we wanted to focus interviews on teachers of students being tested, the teacher sample was restricted to teachers teaching grade four at base- line and grade six at endline. We then randomly selected three students from their classes, and these students‚Äô parents, for interviews."

Title: Child-Adoption Matching: Preferences for Gender and Race
Main Issue: When trying to replicate the paper, there was no instruction given on which order the replication should be conducted. I tried to do this in different orders, but no matter in which order I tried, I could not generate a set of variables from the program provided and that the tables produced by the only program file that is working do not provide any meaningful result.
Data Comments: "Our dataset was constructed by following the matching process of an online adoption facilitator between 2004 and 2009. The dataset is comprised of 840 cases of either born or unborn children that the facilitator collected from multiple agencies and posted on a website designed for client PAPs. On the website, each child is identified by a code, by an array of attributes, by the adoption finalization costs, and by a set of restrictions imposed by the BMO specifying which categories of PAPs she considers acceptable (such as straight couples, same-sex couples, etc)."
